cosmology.name: The Great Wheel
cosmology.description: The default D&D cosmology includes more than two dozen planes. The most common understanding visualizes them as a group of concentric wheels, with the material realms at the center. The Inner Planes form a wheel around the Material Plane, enveloped in the Ethereal Plane. The Outer Planes form another wheel arranged according to alignment, with the Outlands linking them all.

alternateConfigurations.name: World Tree
alternateConfigurations.description: Planes situated among the roots and branches of a great cosmic tree (literally or figuratively)

alternateConfigurations.name: Astral Above Elemental Below
alternateConfigurations.description: Material realms suspended between two other realities: the astral realms (the Astral Plane and the Outer Planes) above and the elemental realms (the Inner Planes) below

alternateConfigurations.name: Simplified Cosmology
alternateConfigurations.description: A cosmology with fewer planes: a Material Plane; the Transitive Planes; a single undifferentiated Elemental Plane; an Overheaven where good deities and Celestials dwell; and an Underworld where evil deities and Fiends reside

alternateConfigurations.name: Orbital Cosmology
alternateConfigurations.description: Planes arranged in a complex system of orbits, with planes exerting greater influence on the Material Plane the closer they draw to it

planeCategories.name: Material Realms
planeCategories.description: Most D&D worlds are located on the Material Plane, which has two planar echoes: the Feywild and the Shadowfell.

planeCategories.name: Transitive Planes
planeCategories.description: The Ethereal Plane and the Astral Plane are boundless realms that provide passage between other planes of existence.

planeCategories.name: Inner Planes
planeCategories.description: The four Elemental Planes (Air, Earth, Fire, and Water), plus the Para-elemental Planes between them.

planeCategories.name: Outer Planes
planeCategories.description: Seventeen Outer Planes correspond to the nine alignments and shades of philosophical difference between them.

planeCategories.name: Positive and Negative Planes
planeCategories.description: These two planes enfold the rest of the cosmology, providing the raw forces of life and death that underlie all existence in the multiverse.

planes.name: Ysgard
planes.philosophicalEssence: Glory earned through heroic deeds in battle. The euphoria of an athlete, the exhilaration of a summer storm, and the triumphant celebration of victory.
planes.emotionalInfluence: Ysgard can overlook the horrors of war and focus entirely on the glory. Since those who die on the plane return to life to fight again the next day, combat is lighthearted and without permanent consequences.

physicalProperties.shape: Continents floating above oceans of volcanic rock, below which are enormous icy caverns
physicalProperties.atmosphereNotes: Windswept battlefields, soaring mountains, and deep fjords

temperature.description: Summers that are long and hot and winters that are cold and unforgiving

physicalProperties.dominantElement: Earth and Fire (volcanic rock oceans beneath floating continents)
physicalProperties.weatherPatterns: Long hot summers and cold unforgiving winters, windswept battlefields

layers.name: Ysgard
layers.description: Immense rivers of floating earth grind together in eternal rumbling. A rugged realm of soaring mountains, deep fjords, and windswept battlefields. Continents float above oceans of volcanic rock.

notableLocations.name: Plain of Ida
notableLocations.description: Located on the topmost layer of Ysgard, where daily festivals let warriors and athletes show off their bravery and skill.

layers.environmentalDescription: Immense rivers of floating earth grind together in eternal rumbling. Soaring mountains, deep fjords, and windswept battlefields.

layers.name: Muspelheim
layers.description: The ground smokes and burns beneath the earthbergs of the top layer.

layerSpecificHazards.name: Smoking and Burning Ground
layerSpecificHazards.description: The ground smokes and burns beneath the earthbergs of the top layer, presenting a hazardous volcanic environment.

layers.environmentalDescription: Volcanic and fiery landscape beneath the floating earthbergs of the topmost layer.

layers.name: Nidavellir
layers.description: Floating chunks of earth are closer together, giving the appearance of endless tunnels with rich mineral deposits.
layers.environmentalDescription: Floating chunks of earth closer together forming vast tunnel-like caverns with rich mineral deposits. Enormous icy caverns hold entire kingdoms.

timeFlow.description: Time flows normally on Ysgard. Creatures killed in combat are restored to life at dawn the next day.

portals.name: Glorium Gate
portals.colorOrAppearance: Gate-town of Glorium in the Outlands leads to Ysgard

planarConnections.name: Yggdrasil, the World Tree
planarConnections.description: Most of Yggdrasil's massive trunk rises through the plane of Ysgard, and its branches stretch through the Upper Planes and across the Astral to the Material Plane. Its roots stretch into the Lower Planes, touching Hades, Pandemonium, and possibly other Lower Planes.
hazards: Ever-changing paths as the tree continues its eternal growth
navigableBy: Planar travelers who climb among the roots and branches
Expert guides who study the ever-changing paths

civilizations.name: Kingdoms of the Icy Caverns
civilizations.description: Entire kingdoms of giants, humans, dwarves, gnomes, and other beings hold court in enormous icy caverns below the floating continents.
civilizations.location: Below the floating continents, in the icy caverns of the lower layers

resurrectionRule.requirement: killed in combat while in Ysgard

savingThrow.triggerDescription: After finishing a Long Rest on Ysgard, a Fiend makes a DC 10 Constitution saving throw because Ysgard is an Upper Plane opposed to the Fiend's nature.

onFailure.description: Whenever the creature makes a D20 Test, the creature must subtract 1d4 from the roll. The effect is cumulative with each failed save.
onFailure.duration: Until the creature finishes a Long Rest on a plane that isn't opposed to its nature
onFailure.cumulativeDescription: The 1d4 penalty is cumulative with each failed save, stacking additional 1d4 subtractions.

onSuccess.description: No additional planar dissonance penalty is imposed for this Long Rest.

savingThrow.repeatSaveTiming: After each Long Rest on the plane
savingThrow.recoveryTrigger: Finishing a Long Rest on a plane that isn't opposed to the creature's nature
recoveryMethods: Finishing a Long Rest on a plane that isn't opposed to the creature's nature

planarDissonance.description: Fiends who visit Ysgard (an Upper Plane) experience significant discomfort if their visits last more than a few hours. After finishing a Long Rest on Ysgard, a Fiend makes a DC 10 Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, whenever the creature makes a D20 Test, the creature must subtract 1d4 from the roll. The effect is cumulative with each failed save and ends when the creature finishes a Long Rest on a plane that isn't opposed to its nature.

domainsOrRegions.name: Glorium
domainsOrRegions.description: The gate-town in the Outlands that is built around a portal leading to Ysgard. It shares many of the characteristics of Ysgard.

adventureThemes: Glory earned through heroic deeds in battle
Testing martial and athletic skill in daily festivals
Exploring secrets buried in deep caverns
Confronting giants, dragons, and mighty creatures

adventureSituations.situation: Characters find themselves on the Plain of Ida on the topmost layer of Ysgard, where daily festivals let warriors and athletes show off their bravery and skill.
Characters venture into the lower layers to face greater challenges or uncover secrets buried in the deep caverns of the plane.
Characters test their mettle against giants, dragons, and other mighty creatures across Ysgard's vast terrain.

globalPlanarConnections.name: Yggdrasil, the World Tree
globalPlanarConnections.description: The World Tree, Yggdrasil, is a cosmic ash tree that spans the Outer Planes and links them to many worlds of the Material Plane. Its roots stretch into the Lower Planes, touching Hades, Pandemonium, and possibly other Lower Planes. Most of its massive trunk rises through the plane of Ysgard, and its branches stretch through the Upper Planes and across the Astral to the Material Plane.
hazards: Ever-changing paths as the tree continues its eternal growth
navigableBy: Planar travelers who climb among the roots and branches
Expert guides who study the ever-changing paths

globalPlanarConnections.name: Infinite Staircase
globalPlanarConnections.description: An extradimensional staircase that connects the planes. An entrance usually appears as a nondescript door. Beyond the portal lies a small landing with a stairway leading up and down. The Infinite Staircase changes appearance as it climbs and descends.
hazards: Guardians such as devas, sphinxes, yugoloths, and other powerful monsters
navigableBy: Any creature that can find an entrance

globalPlanarConnections.name: River Oceanus
globalPlanarConnections.description: The water of the Oceanus is sweet and fragrant, as befits its headwaters in the Blessed Fields of Elysium. It flows through each of Elysium's layers, passes through the top layer of the Beastlands, streams across the top layer of Arborea, and finally drains away somewhere in Arborea's second layer.

globalPlanarConnections.name: River Styx
globalPlanarConnections.description: The River Styx bubbles with grease, foul flotsam, and the putrid remains of battles along its banks. It churns through the top layers of Acheron, the Nine Hells, Gehenna, Hades, Carceri, the Abyss, and Pandemonium.
hazards: Ill effects of the Styx waters
navigableBy: Sinister ferries crewed by skilled pilots
Souls of dead creatures from the Material Plane

planarTravelMethods.name: Planar Portals
planarTravelMethods.description: A portal is a stationary, interplanar connection that links a specific location on one plane to a specific location on another. Some function like doorways, others are locations that exist on multiple planes at once or flicker from one plane to another.
requirements: Meeting portal requirements (command, key item, random timing, situation, or time-based)
risks: Portal requirements may be difficult to meet
destinations: Any plane connected by the specific portal

planarTravelMethods.name: Planar Travel Spells
planarTravelMethods.description: A number of spells allow direct or indirect access to different planes of existence.
requirements: Ability to cast the relevant spell
risks: Varying degrees of precision in destination
destinations: Any plane depending on the spell used

planarTravelMethods.name: Astral Color Pools
planarTravelMethods.description: Gateways leading from the Astral Plane to other planes appear as two-dimensional pools of rippling colors, 1d6 x 10 feet in diameter. The color indicates the destination plane.

planarAdventureSituations.situation: When magic fails to revive a dead person, the only solution is to venture to the Outer Planes to find the person's spirit and either release it from some prison or convince the person to return to life.

People who venture into the woods keep accidentally wandering into the Feywild or the Shadowfell. They might never return, return with no sense of how much time has passed, or return dramatically changed.
A long-dead oracle is the only one who knows how a terrible prophecy might be averted, but the cataclysmic fulfillment of the prophecy has already begun.
A god has stopped answering prayers and won't respond to any Commune spell.
A devil has tricked an angel into meddling in the Blood War, and the angel seeks mortal aid.
An ancestor of one of the characters must be convinced to bless the character before the full power of the character's bloodline can be unleashed.
A foolhardy knight carried a holy weapon on a doomed mission into the Nine Hells, and the powers of Mount Celestia want the weapon and the knight's remains retrieved.
A titan is imprisoned on an Outer Plane. The characters might be trying to stop those who seek to release it, or they might want to release it to help defend the world from a greater threat.

To prove themselves worthy of an even greater quest, the characters are sent to slay a horrible monster, win the favor of a powerful planar being, negotiate peace between two warring planar factions, or retrieve a long-lost item on another plane.
An item of legend is being sold at auction in Sigil, the City of Brass, or some other planar metropolis.

globalPlanarDissonance.description: Celestials who visit the Lower Planes and Fiends who visit the Upper Planes experience significant discomfort if their visits last more than a few hours. After finishing a Long Rest on a plane that is alien to its nature, a Celestial or Fiend makes a DC 10 Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, whenever the creature makes a D20 Test, the creature must subtract 1d4 from the roll. The effect is cumulative with each failed save and ends when the creature finishes a Long Rest on a plane that isn't opposed to its nature.

savingThrow.triggerDescription: After finishing a Long Rest on a plane that is alien to the creature's nature

onFailure.description: Whenever the creature makes a D20 Test, the creature must subtract 1d4 from the roll. The effect is cumulative with each failed save.
onFailure.duration: Until the creature finishes a Long Rest on a plane that isn't opposed to its nature
onFailure.cumulativeDescription: Each failed save adds another 1d4 subtraction to all D20 Tests

onSuccess.description: No additional planar dissonance penalty for this Long Rest.

savingThrow.repeatSaveTiming: After each Long Rest on the opposed plane
savingThrow.recoveryTrigger: Finishing a Long Rest on a plane that isn't opposed to the creature's nature
recoveryMethods: Finishing a Long Rest on a plane that isn't opposed to the creature's nature

savingThrowProbabilities.formula: P(fail | modifier m) = max(0.05, min(0.95, (DC - 1 - m) / 20))
